bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 13, 1875

div1.p: Reed writes that he has not heard from her, and he feels dejected. He attends a reception with a heavy heart.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 13, 1875
div1.p:
I fully
expected a letter from you, this
morning, but as none came, I must
bear my disappointment- You lit-
tle know, how anxious I am to hear
from you, my little darling; espec-
ially since my recent cruel
treatment of you- I suppose
you are awaiting the reception of my letter in
answer to yours before you
write. Mine will reach you
to-day; perhaps just as I write
this sentence you are reading
it. What would I not give
to know your thoughts when
you have read it? Will she
forgive me? This I ask myself,
and the answer comes quickly & plainly, “No”!
“You have wounded her too deeply to be easily
forgiven- Her love was once yours, but your
own folly has banished it”! Too true! Alas!
too true, I fear! You remember that I have often
told you that I am nothing but a poor
foolish boy unworthy of your love- and though
you did not then give your assent to my opinion
of myself, I am sure that, at present, you are
convinced of the fact. And the knowledge of
the fact that I have so fully displayed
my utter unworthiness of your affection causes
me to turn away from myself with
utter disgust! yes, I loathe my very
existence! worthless, worse than worth-
less! I'll cease, however, for I know such
language will make you sad, but never
so sad as the knowledge, that I have
forfeited all claim to your love & re-
spect, makes me. O! to think that I whose
pride it was to thinksay that I would never
wound the feelings of her whom I had promised
to love, that I should have forgotten this &
should have “heaped continual censure” upon
you, my darling, who was entirely innocent
this it is that makes me tremble for the Future!
my promises! what are they? And how are
they kept? swept away like the chaff be-
fore the driving winds! Trampled under foot
without a moment's thought! Would to
Heaven that I had some stability! Some
“calmness and deliberation”! But of these you
say, my darling E, that I have none- Even she
has found it out & whispered it in my ear!
This I accept- To the Past I have given all my
promises, for the Future I have not so much
as one! Oh! the depths of my sorrow!
would to God that there was some one heart that would
give me its sympathy! As it is, I have not so much as one.
But whose fault is it that
I find myself without sym-
pathy? Nobody's but my own-
How can I expect to have your
love and sympathy, when I
have done so much to for-
feit it! Oh! Emilie, love, I cast
myself at your feet, & implore
your forgiveness! Do not cease
to love me, because I have so
fully borne out your expectations
of being “harsh & exacting”-
bitter, bitter words to bear!
In order to change the line
of thought & not pursue a
subject that is full of sor-
row & regret to me, I'll tell
you of a reception I atten-
ded, a few night's ago, at
Majors King's- It was given
in honor of a visit of
Captain Heap, who had been married to a
Washington lady, a few days before- I did not
go with a light heart, & would have much
preferred to remain at home & read my books.
But politeness & military etiquette required me
to be present & to put on a smiling face.
I arrived about 9.30 P.M & found the parlors
well-filled with gentlemen & ladies- seven-
teen of the former & 12 of the latter- I was
presented to the bride, who was a pretty, young,
& smiling creature, looking withal very happy-
and I wondered how long she would retain
she would retain that smile on her
countenance, & when it was banished,
would it be due to a husband's cruelty &
indifference! I turned away &, in a few
moments, found myself in the midst of a
cheerful group- There were a few young
ladies present, but I did not so much as
say one word to them. I left that for others
to do- I did not care to talk to but one young lady,
& she was many miles away. So I paid my
addresses to the married ladies & did my best
to entertain them. At 12.30 the assembly
showed signs of dispersing & I took the
first opportunity to steal away.

I would fill the rest of the page, if I knew
what to write, but as I do not, I will desist.
div1.closer:
I am, as ever, my darling E,
your fond & devoted Walter.
